title-group.article-title: Investor Perception of the International Accounting Standards Quality
title-group.subtitle: Inferences From Germany

abstract.p: The paper analyses whether the adoption of the IAS regime implies an improvement of the firms' earnings quality. Referring to a sample of German listed companies reporting under the IAS and German GAAP (HGB) in 2000-2004 years, we first examine whether IAS adopters are less subject to earnings management. Our findings show that, in general, the IAS sub-sample exhibits a level of earnings management lower or equal to the HGB adopters. The general evidence supports the position of the International Accounting Standard Board and of that part of the academic literature stating the IAS's better quality. Secondly, we investigate whether investors perceive a lower level of uncertainty and information asymmetry for earnings under the IAS regime, after controlling for the level of the discretionary accruals. We find that the IAS adoption entails a lower information asymmetry, but this benefit decreases with the firm size. This means that investors perceive the benefits of higher-quality accounting standards as partially offset by a greater managerial discretion in the small and medium size firms. Therefore, the improvement of the enforcement mechanisms (in addition to the Standard's quality) should be a major concern for IASB and other regulators.

body.p: In the debate on the benefits of International Accounting Standards (IAS) adoption versus country-specific Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) or U.S. GAAP, part of the literature has tried to demonstrate the superior quality of IAS through different measures: the reduction of the cost of capital (Bhattachary, Desai, & Venkataraman, 2010; Cuijpers & Buijink, 2005; Ernstberger & Vogler, 2008; Karamanou & Nishiotis, 2009; Leuz & Verrecchia, 2000), the value relevance of earnings (Barth, Landsman, & Lang, 2008; Bartov, Goldberg, & Kim, 2005; Hung & Subramanyam, 2007; Schiebel, 2007), earnings management, timely loss recognition, and earnings smoothing (Barth et al., 2008; Chen, Tang, Jiang, & Lin, 2010; Ronen & Sadan, 1981). However, most of the literature has provided mixed empirical results and there is no any conclusive evidence that IAS provide a better-quality accounting framework for investors and stakeholders with respect to U.S. GAAP or even other country-specific GAAP.

One inner limitation of this field of accounting literature is that there is no agreed on definition of the accounting quality concept, which is multifaceted and context specific (Dechow, Ge, & Schrand, 2010; Schipper & Vincent, 2003).

Therefore, the previous literature findings investigating the IAS accounting quality cannot be interpreted homogeneously because they employ many different accounting quality proxies, various institutional contexts (one-country or cross-country studies), and different sample periods and research designs.

Actually, accounting quality is affected by many factors other than the accounting principles adopted, such as the legal and political systems, the financial reporting incentives, and other market forces (Ball, Robin, & Wu, 2003; Christensen, Lee, & Walker, 2008; Soderstrom & Sun, 2007).

According to Accounting Standards Setters (International Accounting Standards Board [IASB] and Financial Accounting Standards Board [FASB]), accounting quality relates to the decision usefulness of the financial reporting for investors and stakeholders, in general (IASB, 2006; Schipper & Vincent, 2003). The quality of the financial reporting, in fact, strictly depends on the relevance and reliability of the financial and nonfinancial information recognized and disclosed: The higher the relevance and reliability of accounting data, the better the capability of the market participants to forecast the uncertainty and timing of the firm’s future cash flows.

Assuming this perspective of a direct link between accounting quality and decision usefulness for investors, our study aims to investigate whether the adoption of the IAS framework implies a better accounting quality (i.e., a better information content to investors) with respect to the local GAAP (Handelsgesetzbuch [HGB]) for German firms.

The German setting is unique because since 1998 and until 2005, when IAS adoption became mandatory for all European-listed companies, German firms were allowed to adopt IAS instead of the local GAAP for their consolidated financial reporting. Therefore, we can contrast the earnings properties and market effects of earnings announcements for companies reporting under local GAAP (HGB) and IAS during the same period (2000-2004) and in the same country, and infer the different level of decision usefulness for investors of the two alternative accounting regimes.

As we only consider firms that voluntarily adopted IAS instead of local GAAP for their consolidated financial reporting, we exclude from our sample the companies listed on the New Market (Neuer Markt), which were mandated to choose between IAS and U.S. GAAP (HGB adoption was not allowed).

The assessment of the accounting quality of two alternative regimes from the perspective of their information content for the market participants requires us to choose among different metrics that previous literature has shown to be relevant.

In fact, there is an extensive literature which rests on accounting-based measures to proxy for the degree of the accounting quality, whereas another part of the literature focuses on market-based measures. Drawing on the prior literature, we analyze the earnings quality of IAS and HGB regimes by combining both accounting- and market-based metrics.

Studies focusing on the accounting metrics consider earnings quality as directly related to earnings persistence (Dechow & Schrand, 2004; Penman, 2003; Richardson, 2003). According to this view, accounting quality is an inverse function of the magnitude of the accrual components of earnings because accruals have lower persistence than cash flows and are easier to manipulate (Richardson, Sloan, Soliman, & Tuna, 2005; Sloan, 1996).

Therefore, our first research question is addressed to investigate whether the IAS regimes is characterized by a lower degree of discretionary accruals with respect to the HGB regime, consistently with the position of the International Standards Board and that part of the literature which emphasize the higher quality of the international standards (Barth, 2007; Barth et al., 2008; Bartov et al., 2005; Chen et al., 2010; Hung & Subramanyam, 2007; Barth, Konchitchki, & Landsman, 2010).

Specifically, we focus on the abnormal or discretionary accruals as metrics of earnings management across different industries, which have been shown to be relevant for the investors by previous empirical research (Dechow & Dichev, 2002; J. Jones, 1991). Given the inverse relationship between the earnings quality and the degree of abnormal accruals, we expect the IAS firms to exhibit a lower level of abnormal accruals for each industry.

Accruals and earnings management provide just a “partial measure” of the firms’ accounting quality. Market effects and the information benefits associated with the IAS adoption are driven by further factors, such as the disclosure of other financial and nonfinancial information in the footnotes, the level of enforcement of the accounting principles, the degree of the investor protection, and other managerial incentives.

Therefore, our second research question aims to examine whether, given a certain level of earnings management, investors perceive a greater earnings quality for firms reporting under the IAS regime, rather than the local GAAP. In particular, we examine whether the IAS adoption conveys an information benefit to investors per se (with respect to HGB) and, consequently, whether investors perceive less uncertainty around the earnings announcements of voluntary IAS adopters, independently from the level of earnings management.

For this purpose, we consider the trading volume as our “market-based” proxy for accounting quality. Theoretical and empirical studies support the idea that trading volume around the earnings announcement is induced by different aspects of investors’ disagreement (Atiase & Bamber, 1994; Bamber, Barron, & Stober, 1997, 1999; Karpoff, 1986; Ziebart, 1990), even without any change in market prices. Consistently, we expect IAS adopters to present a lower trading volume around the earnings announcement and abnormal accruals to be negatively related to the trading volume.

Our empirical analysis of the earnings management differences between the IAS and HGB adopters provides evidence of a better earnings quality for the IAS adopters in some industries, but there is no any significant difference for consumer services.

These results are consistent with only a part of the previous research comparing German GAAP with IAS (Barth et al., 2008) because some studies cannot detect a different level of earnings management between the two regimes. In fact, Van Tendeloo and Vanstraelen (2005) show that voluntary IFRS adopters do not present different earnings management with respect to German GAAP users, confirming that high quality standards are not sufficient and effective to guarantee a lower earnings management in countries with weak investor protection rights.

Similarly, Goncharov and Zimmermann (2006), analyzing German-listed companies during the period 1996 to 2002, find that even if the level of earnings management under U.S. GAAP is significantly lower, the manipulation under German GAAP and IAS is roughly the same.

Our analysis suggests that different results and interpretations of prior research may be driven by the reference to different sample periods because in 1998 significant changes to the IAS principles were introduced and IAS users were required to comply in full with the IAS principles, forbidding any partial fulfillment. Moreover, even the sample composition by industries may play a role in explaining the diversity of results of previous studies.

The analyses based on the trading volume around the earnings announcements evidence a positive relationship with the level of abnormal accruals (lower earnings quality) and a negative one with the interaction between IAS adoption and firm size. This means that investors perceive a lower uncertainty and a higher informative content, especially for the IAS numbers of large companies, but this positive effect is decreasing with the firms’ size.

These results indicate that investors recognize an increasing degree of managerial discretion in implementing IAS with the reduction of the firm size, and, consequently, earnings of smaller firms are considered less reliable even if they are under the IAS regime.

Although the German market has already been explored, we complement previous literature with a different perspective. In fact, although our earnings management analysis is similar in scope to the study of Van Tendeloo and Vanstraelen (2005), we refer to a different sample, a longer period (2000–2004), and a different set of regression models for detecting discretionary accruals.
We provide evidence of a superior earnings quality for IAS adopters in general, but results vary across different industries and there is no any significant difference for consumer services.

We also contribute to the literature on the accounting quality and trading volume. In fact, previous studies that examine the investors’ disagreement around earnings announcements (Bamber et al., 1997, 1999; Beaver, 1998; Karpoff, 1986; Kim & Verrecchia, 1991) do not provide a specific focus on the quality of the IAS regime. To our knowledge, this is the first study which measures the reliability and information asymmetry of the IAS and HGB regimes by using the level of uncertainty perceived by investors around the earnings announcements, as captured by the trading volume.

The remainder of the article is organized as follows: the section titled “The German Accounting System” provides an overview of the German accounting system, the section titled “Literature Review and Hypotheses Development” discusses prior studies on earnings management and trading volume and presents our hypotheses, the section titled “Research Design” describes the sample selection, the models and variables, the section titled “Empirical Results” presents the results of the earnings management and trading volume analyses, and in the last section we report our conclusions.

sec.title: The German Accounting System
sec.p: Since 2005, all publicly traded European companies are required to prepare consolidated accounts under IAS. In Germany, many listed companies already applied IAS on a voluntary basis before 2005. In fact, as of April 1998, Germany (and some other European countries) allowed publicly listed companies to prepare their consolidated financial reporting according to IAS instead of German GAAP (Van Tendeloo & Vanstraelen, 2005). Furthermore, in 1998, a new set of core IAS was enacted and a full compliance with the standards was required (forbidding the partial compliance, common before 1998).

Companies could also provide additional individual accounts under IAS, but the individual financial reporting of the legal entity under the German GAAP remained compulsory as it was the reference for tax purposes and for determining the distributable income.
The German GAAP encompasses all codified and noncodified rules, standards, and norms a company has to observe when preparing financial statements (Leuz & Wüstemann, 2004).
Accounting principles and rules are enacted by the legislature and codified in the German Commercial Code (HGB) and not released by a private standard setter.

Historically, German firms have heavily relied on debt, usually provided by few banks. Large ownership blocks by other corporations or individuals are common, with banks often owning shares and acting as trustees for the funds of small investors. Thus, the objectives of the German accounting system are to preserve equity, protect creditors, and facilitate the computation of taxable income.

The “true and fair” view concept is subordinated to compliance with individual provisions of law and the dominant principle of valuation is prudence, not accounting usefulness for investors’ decision. As a result, German accounting is in general rather conservative.

In some contexts, accounting conservatism has been argued to be a quality attribute of earnings. Ball, Kothari, and Robin (2000) argue that “timeliness and conservatism together capture much of the commonly used concept of financial statement transparency” (p. 2). Consequently, empirical measures of conservatism have been used to operationalize financial reporting quality (Ball et al., 2003).

German firms generally engaged in earnings smoothing to reduce the volatility of reported earnings. Earnings smoothing was facilitated by the allowed use of hidden reserves, which could be created when profits were high (by building up unjustified provisions through excessive depreciations of assets or setting aside certain profits in tax-free reserves) and released in periods of losses or low earnings.

With the increase of public equity financing, investors criticized this practice and the lack of detailed disclosures. Companies choosing to adopt IAS need to give up the creation of hidden reserves that makes earnings management more difficult. Moreover, IAS require more disclosures (Ashbaugh, 1999; Leuz & Verrecchia, 2000) and have fewer accounting choices (d’Arcy, 2000) than German GAAP, with a consequent reduction of information asymmetry.

sec.title: Literature Review and Hypotheses Development
sec.p: Two streams of literature are strictly related to our study: earnings quality and trading volume studies.

Earnings quality was differently measured in accounting, but most of the accrual-based literature refers to two basic models and their subsequent modifications: the Jones and the Dechow–Dichev model. Their effectiveness in detecting discretionary accruals finds empirical support also in a recent examination of a wide range of models (K. Jones, Krishnan, & Melendrez, 2008).

Jones (1991) measures earnings management through the estimation error of the regression model, referring to the discretionary components of total accruals,1 differently from previous literature, (McNichols & Wilson, 1988), which only considered some components of the accruals.
In particular, the author assumes that accruals react to the current change in sales but that lagged and future changes are not relevant.

Dechow, Sloan, and Sweeney (1995) show that the original Jones model has low power in cases where firms manipulate revenue through the misstatement of net accounts receivable. To mitigate the discretion exercised over revenues, the authors suggest the use of cash revenue (i.e., revenues less accounts receivable) in place of reported revenue.

Dechow and Dichev (2002) define earnings quality in terms of the relationship between accruals and cash flows, and suggest a measure of the working capital accrual quality based on the observation that accruals shift or adjust the recognition of cash flows over time. The quality of accruals and earnings is inversely related to the standard deviation of the residuals (“discretionary” or “unexpected” accruals) measured in terms of changes on last year, present year, and 1 year-ahead cash flows from operations. A higher standard deviation means lower quality.
McNichols (2002) tries to link the Jones and Dechow–Dichev models.

The author criticizes the Dechow–Dichev assumptions, as they do not separately consider how total accruals might be affected by the behavior of discretionary accruals. Prior literature (Demski & Frimor, 1999; Healy, 1985; McCulloch & Black, 2003) suggests that estimation errors caused by management discretion are not likely to be independent of each other and of the cash flow realizations, thus estimation errors are not necessarily the results of a voluntary manipulation.
In fact, their approach requires that the key element of accruals/earnings quality is in the current accruals and this limits its applicability to firms with short-term cycle of operations.

Considering the misspecification in both models (the residuals in the Jones model are significantly associated with lagged, current, and future cash flows, whereas those in the Dechow–Dichev model are significantly correlated with the change in sales), McNichols (2002) suggests their combination.

Therefore, we analyze the earnings quality under the IAS and HGB regimes during the years 2000 to 2004 with reference to both the working capital accruals, as represented by the Dechow–Dichev model, and the total accruals, as captured by a modified-Jones (MJ) model that combines the Dechow et al. (1995) and the Dechow–Dichev models, to eliminate possible biases.

Literature shows that the earnings quality is inversely related to discretionary or to abnormal accruals (Barth et al., 2008; Dechow & Dichev, 2002; J. Jones, 1991); therefore, we expect that their magnitude for IAS voluntary adopters is lower than or equal to for HGB firms. This leads to our first verifiable hypothesis:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1: The level of earnings management for the IAS-reporting firms is lower than for the HGB-reporting firms.

sec.p: Referring to the second stream of literature, trading volume is considered a proxy of the opinion divergence around the earnings announcements (event window), since investors price divergent opinions as a risk factor (Garfinkel & Sokobin, 2006; Varian, 1985). In fact, abnormal trading volume around earnings announcement dates should reflect the investors’ nonhomogeneous opinions of the public announcement, even when market prices do not change; higher quality accounting data should reduce the divergent opinions of the market, resulting in a negative relationship with the trading volume.
Trading volume has been used in the accounting and financial literature in different contexts.

Karpoff (1986) links returns with trading volume, and the model describes two different informational events affecting trading volume. Investor disagreement leads to increased trading, but volume can increase even if investors interpret information identically, if they also have had divergent prior expectations. Volume is lower in a costly market and volume increases caused by an informational event tend to persist after the event period.

Bamber et al. (1997) illustrate three different aspects of disagreement: “Dispersion in prior beliefs” (the level of variation in expectations before the earnings announcements), “belief jumbling” (investors’ beliefs change positions relative to each other around the earnings announcement), and “change in dispersion” (the difference in the level of dispersion in beliefs after versus before the interim earnings announcement). Each of them affects investors’ real economic (i.e., trading) decisions and plays an important role in explaining trading volume around earnings announcements that is not explained by the price reaction. In particular, trading volume around earnings announcements increases in all three cases of disagreement.

Choi and Kim (2001) explain the dynamics underlying the investor’s opinion divergence, focusing on the news characteristics of earnings announcements as determinants of the degree of underreaction. If two firms share the same firm characteristics and even though their announcements generate the same magnitude of surprise in terms of standardized unexpected earnings, the reaction of investors might differ depending on the characteristics of the news.

Li, Xie, and Xu (2005) investigate the association between trading volume and the magnitudes (i.e., the absolute values) of accruals around quarterly earnings announcement dates. They separate total accruals into discretionary accruals and nondiscretionary accruals and find that trading volume is positively related to the magnitudes of accruals (i.e., they are a source of investor disagreement).
Our contribution to the trading volume and accounting quality literature relates to the debate on the informational benefits of IAS adoption versus country-specific GAAP.

In particular, we examine whether the voluntary adoption of the IAS regime affects the investors perception of the earnings quality, after having controlled for the level of earnings management and other factors not directly attributable to the accounting regime. Because trading volume around the earnings announcements is directly related to the degree of the investors’ opinion divergence and the level of information asymmetry perceived by the market (Karpoff, 1986; Kim & Verrecchia, 1991; Li, 2005), we expect an inverse relationship between IAS adoption and trading volume.
Therefore, our second hypothesis is as follows:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2: After controlling for the discretionary accrual differences between the IAS and HGB adopters, investors perceive an incremental information benefit and a lower uncertainty for accounting numbers under the IAS regime.

sec.title: Sample Selection
sec.p: The selected sample is based on the German companies, excluding financials and utilities, listed on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. The sample period covers the years 2000 to 2004, but due to model constructions, we require that cash flow data be available from 1999 to 2005.
Sample selection is subject to some limitations related to the focus of the analyses and, especially, to the restrictions on data availability.

First, the reference to a specific country, Germany, is because it is the only large European country with a strong set of local GAAP where a considerable number of firms applied IAS on a voluntary basis before 2005. This allows us to investigate whether the investors perceive a different quality for financial results reported under diverse accounting regimes (IAS and HGB) by holding the main institutional factors constant.

Second, the analytical models employed to measure the abnormal accruals require the availability of cash flow data for 1 year before and after the selected period (i.e., 1999 and 2005). Therefore, computations for the year 2000 are based on cash flow data starting from 1999, that is, the first year after the endorsement (April 1998) of the German law, which allowed the listed companies to prepare their consolidated financial statements in accordance with IAS, U.S. GAAP, or German GAAP.2

Third, as the focus of the analyses is on companies that voluntarily adopted the IAS for their (consolidated) financial reporting in the period 2000 to 2004, we have consistently excluded from our sample the firms listed on the German New Market (Neuer Markt), which were mandated to choose between IAS and U.S. GAAP only (Leuz, 2003).

The German New Market was created in 1997 as a new stock exchange segment specifically devoted to the trading of the stocks of small- and medium-sized, high-growth companies. Those innovative firms were highly exposed to the effects of the “Internet” bubble during the 1999 to 2001 years. Thus, their exclusion has a double implication for our sample: on one hand, it limits the potential bias due to the 1999 to 2001 market bubble, but on the other hand, it reduces the number of observations available from the technology industry.

Fourth, because data requirements are different for the abnormal accruals and trading volume analyses, we have to consider two different samples. One refers to all3 the German companies listed on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in the 1999 to 2005 period and reporting under the HGB or the voluntary IAS regimes, for which data required to perform the abnormal accrual analyses were available. The second sample, used for the trading volume analyses, is a subset of the former because it has to consider only the available (hand collected) earnings announcement data.

sec.p: Every firm-year observation is classified in the IAS or HGB subsample, respectively, according to the accounting regime adopted.

In 2000, the total sample consists of 41 firms reporting under IAS and 103 reporting under HGB. During the considered period, many HGB firms switched to IAS and in the last year (2004) the sample is composed of 110 IAS firms and only 50 HGB firms (Table 2). Thus, a great part of observations in the HGB and IAS subsamples actually comes from the same firms, adopting first the HGB principles and then the IAS regime.

Computation of the working capital accruals relies on 746 observations (368 IAS and 378 HGB), whereas for the total accruals model we consider 742 observations (367 IAS and 375 HGB). This small difference in the number of observations between the two accrual models is due to the diverse data requirements and availability, but it does not imply any significant difference in the distribution of the firm-year observations across the industries, the accounting regimes, and the years. Therefore, for simplicity, in Tables 1 and 2, we only report the distribution of the observations of the main sample used in the working capital accrual computation.

In addition to financial and utility industries excluded for their specific accounting rules, we are also forced to eliminate Telecommunications and Oil and Gas industries, for lack of observations to perform a significant analysis.
Finally, the trading volume analyses consider an event window around the earnings announcement dates for IAS and HGB firms in the fiscal years 2000 to 2004.

The earnings announcement dates for German-listed firms were hand collected from the press releases reported on the companies’ websites and from the newspaper articles retrieved in the LexisNexis database.

Due to the limitations regarding the collection of the earnings announcement dates and the trading volume data, we have a smaller sample available for the trading volume analyses, consisting of 350 observations in total (194 IAS and 156 HGB, as reported in Table 5).
All market and company data, different from earnings announcement dates, were collected from the Datastream, Worldscope, and LexisNexis databases.

sec.title: Models and Variables
sec.p: The first research question considers a specific measure of earnings quality that previous empirical research has shown to be relevant for the investors: the degree of earnings management in terms of abnormal or discretionary accruals.
Given the inverse relationship between the earnings quality and the degree of abnormal accruals, we expect the IAS firms to exhibit a lower level of abnormal accruals.
To test this hypothesis, we consider two alternative measures: working capital accruals and total accruals.
In the first analysis, we use the Dechow–Dichev model for estimating the abnormal (or discretionary) working capital accruals, equal to the residuals of the following regression:

CFOit–1/t/t+1 = operating cash flows6 for Company i in Year t– 1/t/t+ 1 scaled by the average total assets;

In the above formula, we determine the operating cash flows starting from the operating income, which we believe to provide a better metric than the net income before extraordinary items. As the extant literature usually derives accrual measures from the latter variable, we also perform a control analysis through an expanded MJ model that focuses on total accruals and employs a cash flow configuration drawn from the net income before extraordinary items.
Thus, we estimate the abnormal total accruals using a MJ model that combines the Dechow et al. (1995) model and the Dechow–Dichev (2002) model.7

where all variables are scaled by the average total assets and are defined as follows (see Appendix): TAit = (ΔWCAit– DD&Ait) = total accruals for Company i in Year t; ΔWCAit = change in the operating working capital for Company i in Year t (defined as above); DD&Ait = Depreciation, Depletion, and Amortization; CFO_MJit–1/t/t+1 = operating cash flows used in the MJ model calculated as the difference between Net Income Before Extraordinary Items and total accruals (TAit as defined above) for Company i in Year t– 1/t/t+ 1 (all scaled by the average total assets); (ΔREV –ΔAR)it = change in revenues minus change in accounts receivable (i.e., change in the cash revenues) for Company i in Year t (scaled by the average total assets); PPEit = gross amount of property, plant, and equipment for Company i at the end of the Fiscal Year t (scaled by the average total assets).

Both the working capital accrual (Equation 1) and the total accrual (Equation 2) regressions are estimated by pooling all sample year observations for each accounting regime (IAS and HGB) and for each industry (defined according to the ICB classification, stated above).

To compare the degree of earnings management of IAS and HGB firms, we perform statistical tests on the differences in mean and median of the absolute value of the standardized residuals8 from Equations 1 and 2.
To mitigate the effect of few outliers, we truncate the data at the 97th percentile before performing our tests.

Our second research question considers whether investors perceive a greater earnings quality for companies that voluntarily chose to report under the IAS regime, instead of applying the local GAAP, after controlling for earnings management and other factors.

Theory suggests that IAS adoption should improve the financial reporting quality (Barth et al., 2008; Daske, Hail, Leuz, & Verdi, 2008) and that an increase in accounting quality should be relevant to investors by reducing information asymmetries and the cost of capital, and increasing liquidity (Daske et al., 2008; Diamond & Verrecchia, 1991; Kim & Verrecchia, 1994).
Therefore, we have investigated whether the differences in accounting quality between IAS and HGB firms influence the level of information asymmetries perceived by investors.

Based on the previous literature about information asymmetry, we assume that trading volume around the earnings announcement is inversely related to the reliability and information content of the firms’ financial reporting quality, after controlling for other effects that the literature demonstrated to influence trading volume.

As prior literature (Collins, Gong, & Hribar, 2003; Drake, Myers, & Myers, 2009; Francis, LaFond, Olsson, & Schipper, 2005; Sloan, 1996; Thomas & Zhang, 2002; Xie, 2001) provides consistent evidence that accruals are (mis)priced by the investors, we explicitly control for the information effects of the level of the abnormal accruals by using the absolute value of the residuals from Equation 1 and, alternatively, from Equation 2. We expect a strong negative relationship between the trading volume (in the event window around the earnings announcement) and a firm’s level of abnormal accruals, independently from the accounting regime used.

However, earnings management represents only one of the many factors influencing the earnings quality. Thus, our analysis aims to investigate whether the voluntary IAS adoption affects the level of information asymmetries perceived by investors, after controlling for the degree of earnings management.
We empirically measure this further aspect through the interaction between the IAS adoption and the log of the average market cap (LSIZE) variable.

We need to separate the IAS fixed effect and the interaction effect between IAS adoption and size because of the high correlation between the two variables. Indeed, IAS firms are generally larger than HGB firms (Tables 3 and 5)9 and without the interaction term we would obtain a very significant coefficient for the LSIZE variable and a nonsignificant coefficient for the IAS dummy.

This represents a limit in our analysis because we are unable to control for some effects related to the size but unattributable to the financial reporting system per se, such as enforcement, litigation, and incentives to adopt IAS. As clearly stated by Barth et al. (2008), there is no definitive way to determine the degree to which those partial effects influence our results. However, the reference to a homogeneous institutional and economic context and the characteristics of our sample construction should mitigate the effects of factors not attributable to the financial reporting system.

Equations 3 and 4 are estimated by pooling all sample years and for each of the following three different event periods around the date of earnings announcement (Date 0): [–1; +5], [–5; +5], and [–1; +10] days.11

Li et al. (2005) state that the magnitude of cash flow, ABS(CFO), could be a source of differential interpretation of the earnings announcements by the investors, even if to a much lesser extent than accruals. If this is true, we expect a positive relationship between the magnitude of cash flows and the trading volume.
Kim and Verrecchia (1991) indicate that the trading volume around an event announcement is positively related with the absolute value of the change in the stock price during the event period.

Following prior literature (Atiase & Bamber, 1994; Li et al., 2005; Utama & Cready, 1997), we employ the absolute value of the cumulative abnormal returns in the event window (LARET) as our metric for the absolute price change; consistently, we expect a positive coefficient for LARET.

For each year-t announcement, the cumulative abnormal returns (ARET) in the specific event period are calculated as the ratio between the cumulative daily returns (CDRI) and the event period days (n) multiplied by the median of the daily returns (MD_DRI) in the control period (days [–250, –16]), minus one, as follows:

where CDRI = cumulative daily returns in the selected event period; MD_DRI = median of the daily returns in the nonevent (control) period (days [–250, –16]); n = number of days included in the event period.
Consequently, LARET is defined as follows:

We use the absolute value of the abnormal working capital accruals (ABSAWA in Equation 3) and, respectively, abnormal total accruals (ABSATA_MJ in Equation 4) as a control variable representing the degree of the earnings management. Consistently with Li et al. (2005), we expect a positive coefficient on this variable, as the divergences of the investors’ interpretation of the earnings announcement increases with the magnitude of accruals.
The log of the average market capitalization during the control period (LSIZE) is based on Bamber (1986), who showed that the trading volume is inversely related to the size of the firm.

The large firms are more scrutinized by analysts and investors than small firms, and information about their state and perspectives is more widespread; this explains the lower volume reaction to the earnings announcements by the larger firm. Therefore, we expect a negative coefficient on this variable.

Hotchkiss and Strickland (2003) provide evidence that trading volume around the earnings announcements is influenced by the firm’s ownership structure. The variable representing the percentage of closely held shares (CH) captures this effect and is also a proxy for the proportion of rational investors (Choi & Kim, 2001).
Assuming that the percentage of closely held shares is inversely related to the fraction of institutional ownership, we expect its coefficient to be negative.12

The firm’s return volatility (STD_DRI) over the control period (from –250 to –16 days prior to the earnings announcement date) represents a measure of risk that should be negatively related to the post-event trading volume (Garfinkel, 2009; Goyal & Santa-Clara, 2003; Leuz & Verrecchia, 2000; Michaely & Vila 1995, 1996).

To investigate the IAS adoption effects, we consider the following variables: IAS = dummy variable equals to 1 for firms adopting the IAS/IFRS in Year t and 0 otherwise (HGB firms), this variable controls for the fixed effects related to the IAS subsample and we expect a negative coefficient for it; IAS × LSIZE = the interaction effect between the firm size and the IAS adoption. This is the variable we rely on to provide evidence that IAS adopters are subject to a lower information asymmetry due to their superior earnings quality. Thus, we expect a negative coefficient on this variable that captures the incremental information benefit for IAS adopters with respect to the average effect of size.
Finally, in our regression equations, we include the indicator variables for industry and year fixed effects to control the common effects on the dependent variable in a specific year and industry.

sec.title: Results of the Earnings Management Analyses
sec.p: The first set of results regards the earnings management investigation.

These aforementioned analyses rest on a larger sample of data (a total of 746 firm-year observations, 368 IAS, and 378 HGB) with respect to the one used for the trading volume analyses. This is because the latter require the availability of earnings announcement dates and are limited to 2000 to 2004 years.

sec.p: Following the indications of Gassen and Sellhorn (2006) and Gu (2007), we measure the standardized residuals as the absolute value of the ratio between the residuals of Equation 1 (abnormal accruals) and the fitted values.

To mitigate the effect of few outliers, we have performed the mean and median tests of equality of the standardized residuals of the IAS and HGB samples after truncating the data at the 97th percentile.

Except for the basic material and technology industries, the means (medians) of the standardized residuals of the HGB subsample are greater than the means (medians) of the IAS subsample. As the HGB subsample for the technology industry counts very few (seven) observations only, we are very cautious in interpreting the results for this industry.

The mean equality tests13 of the standardized residuals indicate that the differences between the IAS and HGB subsamples are statistically significant for the consumer good, health care, and technology industries.
The results from the Wilcoxon/Mann–Whitney tests on the median values partially diverge in a weak significant difference for industrials and in a not significant difference for consumer goods.

Overall, the evidence based on the Dechow–Dichev model is mixed; we can assert that, with the exception of the technology industry, IAS firms exhibit a degree of earnings management equal to or lower than the HGB adopters, but there is a clear evidence of a better earnings quality for IAS adopters only in the health care industry.

Panel B of Table 4 reports the means and medians of the standardized residuals (calculated with the same procedure as for the Dechow–Dichev model) from the MJ model (Equation 2). In addition, in this case, we are very cautious in interpreting the results for the technology industry because of the limited number of the HGB observations.

The equality tests14 of the means of the standardized residuals from the MJ model now indicate statistically significant differences in the means of the IAS and HGB subsamples, with the exception of the consumer service industry.
The Wilcoxon/Mann–Whitney tests on the medians support the same results, but they do not indicate any significant difference for the industrials and for the consumer services.

The analyses based on the MJ model indicate that IAS adopters exhibit a lower degree of earnings management with respect to the HGB adopters, with the exception of the consumer service industry, for which we are not able to detect any significant difference between IAS and HGB, and the technology industry (whose results could be biased by the lower number of observations).
In summary, the first set of analyses supports the idea that the IAS adopters are generally characterized by a level of earnings management lower than or equal to the HGB adopters.

Our findings could shed more light on the interpretation of the results from the previous empirical literature on the German voluntary IAS adopters. In fact, prior studies did not succeed in demonstrating a clear and significant lower level of earnings management for German IAS adopters with respect to HGB users before 2005. We show that the empirical results depend on the model used for the abnormal earnings analysis and on the sample composition by industries. In fact, the working capital accruals (Dechow–Dichev) model returns a weaker evidence of the better earnings quality for IAS adopters with respect to the MJ model, which focuses on the total accruals.

Furthermore, both models clearly indicate that for the consumer service industry, there is no any significant difference in the degree of earnings management between IAS and HGB adopters; therefore, the specific composition of the sample by industries could be an important determinant of the whole results.

sec.p: The same regressions are applied across different event periods ([–1, +10], [–5, +5], [–1, +5]) around the earnings announcements.

In the first set of regressions (Table 7), the coefficient of the absolute value of operating cash flows, ABS(CFO), does not result significantly different from zero, whereas the other main independent variables are all significant and have the expected sign, with the exception of the IAS indicator.
The coefficient of the abnormal return variable (LARET) is positive, reflecting a direct association with the trading volume, as stated by Kim and Verrecchia (1991).
The negative coefficient on the size variable (LSIZE) indicates that the smaller the firm’s size, the greater the level of the information asymmetry and uncertainty perceived by investors.
The sign of the ownership variable (CH) is negative too, suggesting that a more concentrated ownership induces a lower volume.

The positive sign of the coefficient of the absolute value of the abnormal accruals variable (ABSAWA) indicates that, in general, a greater level of earnings management is associated with a higher trading volume. This confirms that a lower earnings quality is associated with a greater level of uncertainty perceived by investors.

As IAS adoption is positively related with the firm size (Gassen & Sellhorn, 2006; Hung & Subramanyam, 2007; Leuz 2003); we have considered both the IAS variable (equal to 1 for IAS-reporting firms and 0 otherwise) and the interaction effect between this variable and the size (LSIZE × IAS).

The coefficient of the interaction effect is highly significant and negative, meaning that to report under the IAS regime implies an incremental information benefit for investors, but this effect is decreasing with the firm’s size. We interpret this result as the evidence that IAS regime per se is not sufficient to guarantee an information benefit to investors without a strong enforcement of the rules, which is typically weaker for smaller firms.

The coefficient of the IAS dummy is significant but with a positive sign, contrary to our expectation. We deem this is a correction effect due to the direct correlation between the IAS adoption and the firm’s size.
We got a consistent evidence across all the alternative event periods considered in Table 7.
Table 8 presents the same set of analyses as in Table 7 but with explicatory variables (operating cash flows and abnormal accruals) derived from Equation 2 (MJ model).

This set of regressions across the different event periods considered returns results aligned with the previous analysis, even if the coefficient on some variables now is not significant. In particular, the coefficient on the interaction variable LSIZE × IAS is negative and significant, showing a lower information asymmetry for IAS reporting companies, even if decreasing with size.

In conclusion, the overall evidences from the trading volume analyses (Tables 7 and 8) support the view that investors consider the accounting numbers of the IAS firms more reliable and of higher quality, but these benefits decreases with size.

Therefore, considering that in our sample the IAS voluntary adopters are larger than the HGB firms, and given the impossibility to disentangle the effects attributable exclusively to the choice of the accounting regime with respect to other factors, such as incentives and institutional/market factors, we remain cautious in interpreting data.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, we investigate whether investors perceive a better earnings quality for firms reporting under the IAS with respect to the local GAAP.
Our contribution to the literature can be considered under two different perspectives.
First, we examine whether the level of earnings management differs across a sample of German firms voluntarily adopting the IAS or the local standards (HGB) in the 2000 to 2004 period.

Our findings, based on the Dechow–Dichev model, for working capital accruals, and on a MJ model, for the total accruals, provide evidence that the IAS subsample exhibits a level of earnings management lower than or equal to the HGB subsample. This is aligned with the position of the IASB and of that part of the academic literature stating the IAS’s better quality. However, both models support the conclusion that for consumer services, there is not any significant difference between IAS and HGB firms (for technology the opposite seems true, but we do not have enough data to draw reliable conclusions).

We acknowledge that, to some extent, the results may depend on the specific sample selection (our sample excludes financial, utility, and telecom industries and companies listed on the New Market) and the model applied.

The second perspective focuses directly on the investor perception of earnings quality. The analysis is based on the theoretical prediction (Karpoff, 1986; Kim & Verrecchia, 1991) that a higher trading volume reflects a higher uncertainty (and a lower earnings quality) perceived by the investors. Therefore, we investigate the differential earnings quality associate to the IAS regime by performing an event study on the trading volume around the earnings announcement dates. Our results reveal that the trading volume is positively associated with the level of abnormal accruals in general (lower earnings quality), whereas it is negatively associated with the interaction between IAS adoption and size. This result indicates that, for the same degree of earnings management, investors perceive a lower level of information asymmetry for IAS firms, but this effect is decreasing with firm size. Most probably this is due to some contextual factors, such as the intensity of the public scrutiny and the managerial incentives that could lead to a more rigorous enforcement of accounting standards and a better earnings quality for larger firms.

This is consistent with the academic literature (Ball et al., 2003; Christensen et al., 2008) asserting that a high quality accounting regime is just a necessary condition, but not a sufficient one, for reliable and high quality accounting numbers.

Accordingly, a primary concern of the Standard Setters and other regulators should be also the improvement of the enforcement mechanisms of the accounting standards, especially in the European environment characterized by a prominent presence of small and medium companies.

We use the cash flow data for 2005 too, which is the year of mandatory adoption of IAS for all German-listed companies. In theory, the measure of cash flows in 2005 should be independent from the accounting standards adopted. Actually, we acknowledge that mandatory adoption of IAS could introduce a bias in our analysis, because our measures of operating cash flows are not derived from the companies’ statement of cash flows (due to data availability limitations) but represents the difference between the operating income (or Net Income Before Extraordinary Items) and the working capital accruals (total accruals). Usually the studies based on the event study methodology perform sensitivity analyses by referring to alternative sample periods with different lengths. For instance, Bamber (1986), Bamber et al. (2005) refer to a 3-days event period [–1; +1]; Auer (1996) refers to the period [–30; +30]; Garfinkel and Sokobin (2006) consider the period [–1; 0]; Sponholtz (2004) analyzes the [–5; +5] period but finds that the announcement effect is fully incorporated in the [–1; +5] interval.

Previous studies focused on the U.S. context utilized the institutional ownership as a control variable; that information is not available for our sample; consequently, we assume that the percentage of closely held shares is negatively related to institutional ownership.
